想要拍摄令人惊叹的鸟类照片吗？虽然鸟类摄影通常看起来令人畏惧，但实际上非常简单——一旦掌握了窍门。

在这篇文章中，我将分享您需要了解的有关令​​人惊叹的鸟类照片的所有信息，包括：

  • 拍摄动感十足的鸟类的最佳相机设备
  • 完美的鸟类摄影照明
  • 改善作文的简单技巧
  • 大量鸟类摄影示例
  • 很多很多！

因此，如果您准备好成为专家，那么让我们从我的第一个提示开始吧：

1. 选择好的鸟类摄影装备（但不要沉迷于此）

在我看来，开始鸟类摄影需要具备以下条件：一台具有可更换镜头功能的 APS-C 相机，以及至少达到 300 毫米的长焦镜头（不包括 APS-C 裁剪系数）。当我开始担任鸟类摄影师时，我就使用了它，通过正确的方法，我能够捕捉到较大鸟类（天鹅、苍鹭等）甚至较小鸣禽和滨鸟的充满画面的图像。

一旦您变得更加认真并且真正想要提高作为鸟类摄影师的灵活性和命中率，您就会想要升级到更注重动作的设置，同时也提供更大的范围。

现阶段，是时候考虑高速APS-C相机了。它应该具有一流的自动对焦能力和最低 8 FPS 的连拍速度。像佳能 EOS R7 这样专为专业野生动物摄影师设计的相机是不错的选择。这些相机坚固耐用，能够承受雨、泥或沙等具有挑战性的拍摄条件。

现在我们来谈谈镜头。理想情况下，您会想要长度超过 300 毫米的东西。达到 400 毫米的变焦镜头或 400 毫米定焦镜头是一个很好的起点，但如果您的目标是体型更小或更容易受惊的鸟类，请考虑改变游戏规则的 500 毫米或 600 毫米镜头。是的，它们可能很昂贵，但有些变焦镜头可以达到这些超远摄长度而无需花费太多。

注意：如果您想要使用 500 毫米或更长的镜头，购买坚固的三脚架也是一个好主意。它将有助于减少相机抖动（高倍率下的常见问题），并使您的手臂更轻松地进行鸟类摄影。

也就是说，虽然装备可以增强你的能力，但它并不是一切。即使没有最长的镜头或最快的相机，坚持不懈仍然可以拍出令人惊叹的照片。

2. 研究你的主题

我怎么强调都不为过——了解您想要拍摄的鸟类可以极大地提高您的照片质量。你看，鸟类摄影不仅仅是拍摄图像；它还包括鸟类摄影。这是为了捕捉这些迷人生物的本质，这需要深入了解它们的习惯、栖息地和行为。

想象一下，您的目标是在自然栖息地捕捉难以捉摸的笛鸻。了解它们喜欢的休息地点和迁徙时间可能意味着带着空存储卡离开和带着令人惊叹的镜头回家之间的区别。

如何加深对鸟类主题的理解？首先，尝试阅读有关鸟类的书籍和在线文章。当您深入研究这些资源时，请密切关注对象的日常生活、筑巢习惯和最喜欢的食物来源。

接下来，考虑观看以您想要的鸟类为主题的纪录片或在线视频。这些可以让您深入了解它们独特的行为，并让您了解它们喜欢的自然栖息地。

但不要止于被动研究。关于直接观察有很多话要说。考虑花时间观察这些美丽的生物，而不用担心拍摄它们。您将更深入地了解他们的行为，从而拍摄出更引人注目的个人照片。

这可能看起来工作量很大，是的，确实如此。但请记住，鸟类摄影的乐趣在于细节，您对拍摄对象越了解，您就越有可能捕捉到那些使您的作品与众不同的独特时刻。

3.光线合适时拍摄

您可能听说过“黄金时刻”，即清晨或傍晚光线柔和温暖的神奇时刻。这不仅是鸟类摄影的最佳照明，而且也恰逢鸟类活动高峰期。完美的时机，对吧？

强烈的正午阳光可能因其便利性和强度而看起来很有吸引力，但它实际上会产生刺眼的阴影，从而影响您的图像。相反，瞄准那些黄金时间，这有几个好处。它可以柔化鸟类拍摄对象上的阴影，增强其羽毛的光泽，并在它们的眼睛中产生吸引人的目光。

在这些时间里，太阳的位置较低，意味着光线将从背面、侧面或正面照射。请记住这一点，因为不同的角度会产生不同的效果。标准的顺光鸟类摄影是让光线从你的肩膀上射过来，均匀地照亮你的拍摄对象。但不要忽视侧光和逆光 - 它们可以为您的照片添加戏剧性的效果。

阴天是另一种选择。正午的漫射阳光消除了刺眼的阴影，尽管它缺乏黄金时段光线的温暖。此外，您可能很难保持较快的快门速度，尤其是在捕捉飞行中的鸟类时。这并不是说在阴天就不能获得好的结果。它只需要更多的计划和创造力。请记住，在鸟类摄影中，没有一天是真正不可能的。

4.选择较快的快门速度

鸟类几乎不会静止不动。它们飞翔、飞翔、扑腾——如果你的快门速度太慢，你最终会得到模糊的图像。现在，您可能会问，“什么是快快门速度？”在鸟类摄影中，对于运动中的鸟类，您通常需要将快门速度至少设置为 1/1000 秒。

然而，对于飞过天空的鸟儿，您可能需要将其提高到 1/2000 秒。但在这里您可能会遇到一些挑战。

你看，快门速度、光圈和 ISO 一起发挥作用。较快的快门速度会减少进入的光线，因此您需要进行补偿。一种方法是提高 ISO，但要小心。高 ISO 值会引入数字噪声，使图像看起来有颗粒感。

让更多光线进入的另一种方法是使用更大的光圈。现在，更大的光圈意味着更浅的景深，这可能会使鸟的某些部分失去焦点。但这也不全是坏消息。大光圈还可以模糊背景，将注意力集中在鸟儿身上。这一切都是为了找到最适合您的特定场景的平衡。

您可能会想：“听起来很复杂。我该如何处理这一切？”这是一个提示。将相机切换至光圈优先模式。您设置光圈，相机将调整快门速度以获得正确的曝光。当光线快速变化且您没有时间摆弄设置时，它是您的救星。

5.选择合适的鸟类拍摄地点

有时最大的挑战不是拍照，而是找到拍摄对象。你可以拥有世界上所有的技能，但如果周围没有鸟，你就运气不好了。

那么，你在哪里可以找到这些鸟呢？嗯，世界上充满了潜在的鸟类摄影地点。但您需要先做一些侦探工作。查找您所在地区的鸟类栖息地、迁徙模式和鸟类热点。找出鸟儿在哪里以及它们可能何时在那里。

但这里有一句警告。并非所有有鸟类的地方都是摄影的好地方。你可以找到一个充满鸟类的地方，但如果背景杂乱，或者鸟类距离太远，那就行不通了。

当地公园、湿地或自然保护区通常是不错的选择。那里的鸟儿通常更习惯人类，因此您可以靠近它们，而不会吓跑它们。但要做好准备，迎接鸟类不合作的日子。它发生了。

那你怎么办呢？坚持是关键。继续往回走。了解这个地方的节奏、鸟类的活动规律。你的投篮每次都会变得更好。

如果您仍在挣扎，请考虑参加鸟类摄影工作室或旅游。他们可以引导您前往一些最佳地点，并帮助您掌握拍摄令人惊叹的鸟类照片的技巧。

5. 仔细选择鸟类摄影构图

让我们解决鸟类摄影的主要障碍之一——正确构图。如果您是初学者，您可能会发现创建引人注目的图像结构具有挑战性。你看，鸟类摄影是独特的。它不像风景或建筑摄影等其他类型那样依赖复杂的构图。

然而，正确的构图至关重要。为什么？因为它有助于将观众的注意力吸引到主题上。它有助于创造更强烈的视觉冲击力。这是你引导那些观看你的作品的人看到你想让他们看到的东西，感受到你想让他们感受到的东西的方式。

但你怎么能做到这一点呢？如何仅通过提高构图技巧来显着提高鸟类照片的质量？

解决方案比您想象的要简单得多。您可以采用一些关键技术来改变您的鸟类摄影游戏。首先，练习使用三分法。这一摄影的基本原则是摄影师构图的指南。你要做的如下：想象你的框架被分成九个相等的矩形，三个水平的，三个垂直的。现在，将您的鸟放置在其中一条线上或交叉点上。这将为您的照片增添平衡，并使其对观看者更具吸引力。

接下来，考虑空间规则。想想鸟儿面对或移动的方向。在该方向上留出框架空间。这项技术为您的鸟类提供了“移动”的空间，并为您的照片带来了活力。这是野生动物摄影中经常使用的技巧，因为拍摄对象经常在移动。

除此之外，您可能还想尝试不同的框架技术。使用草或花等自然元素来构图你的鸟可以为你的镜头增添额外的兴趣。它提供了鸟类栖息地的背景信息，并有助于突出鸟类本身。

但请记住，这一切并非没有挑战。当您专注于获得完美的构图时，您可能会错过点击鸟类自发动作或独特行为的机会。但不要灰心。通过练习，您将更快地确定最佳构图。您不仅可以捕捉自发的瞬间，还可以捕捉精心构图的镜头。图像的整体美学质量将显着提高，这是值得的。

6. 俯身观察视线水平

我们在五到六英尺高的地方看到我们的世界，但鸟类在离地几英寸到几英尺的地方看到世界。要感受鸟类的世界，请站在它们的高度！

换句话说，不要害怕蹲下、蹲下、爬行或平躺在地上。是的，你可能会变得有点泥泞。然而，这是获得专业外观、低视角图像的关键，如下所示：

以下是低视角鸟类摄影的一些好处：

  • 您将获得真正的眼神交流，拍摄更私密的照片
  • 您将在前景和背景中获得令人愉悦的模糊效果（请注意上图中模糊的沙子）
  • 你会离地面较低，因此对拍摄对象的威胁较小
  • 您将带观众进入鸟类的世界

显然，在某些情况下你无法蹲下，这没关系——但如果可能的话，趴在地上。它可以改变一切。

7. 尽可能练习你的聚焦技巧

您是否曾经结束一天的拍摄回到家，急于查看您的图像，却发现它们并不像您希望的那么清晰？罪魁祸首之一可能是注意力集中。当您的拍摄对象较小、灵活且通常距离很远时，对焦就成为真正的挑战。

这是一个常见的绊脚石。但是，我向你保证，提高你的聚焦能力并不像看起来那么令人畏惧。这是跟踪和捕捉那些快速移动的羽毛朋友的有效方法，从而拍摄出更详细、更引人注目的照片。您将会惊讶于一张聚焦良好的图像可以为您的鸟类摄影作品集带来的转变。

那么，如何提高你的聚焦能力呢？第一步是了解您的相机。掌握自动对焦模式和设置。每台相机都有自己的特点，你的工作就是学习它们。通过这样做，您将能够直观地为每个镜头选择最佳设置。

接下来，练习。当我说练习时，我不仅仅指出去拍摄鸟类。相反，花一些时间用镜头跟踪其他移动的物体。这可以是任何东西，从驶过的汽车到在院子里跑来跑去的狗。这种练习将有助于提高您的焦点跟踪技能，为您进入快速变化的鸟类世界做好准备。

最后，不要低估后退按钮焦点的力量。一开始它看起来有点陌生，但一旦你掌握了它的窍门，它就会改变游戏规则。通过将对焦操作与快门按钮分开，您可以更好地控制对焦内容和对焦时间。

当然，提高聚焦技巧并非没有挑战。看起来你似乎没有取得进展，或者不值得花时间。我向你保证，确实如此。当您查看鸟类照片并看到每根羽毛的清晰细节时，花在掌握焦点上的时间和精力将是值得的。

8.保持眼睛敏锐且光线充足

与鸟类身体的任何其他部分相比，眼睛绝对是百分百需要好看的。

这是什么意思？其一，如果眼睛里没有光，鸟儿就会显得迟钝或毫无生气。而拥有清晰眼睛（称为聚光灯）的鸟类看起来要好得多。

看看下面的照片。你能看到鸟眼里的白色斑点吗？这就是聚光灯，您可以通过将太阳（或其他光源）放在您的背后来获得它。

（快速提示：为了获得最佳的聚光灯，只需将你的影子对准鸟，并确保你的视角与眼睛水平；太阳会完成剩下的工作！）

您还应该确保鸟瞰始终、始终、始终处于焦点位置。如果眼睛模糊但身体敏锐，那么你就失败了；如果身体模糊但眼睛敏锐，你仍然可以拍出好照片。

9. 学习如何像专业人士一样追踪鸟类

鸟类是易受惊吓的动物。突然移动，或者走得太近，它们就会离开。那么如何拍摄特写镜头而不吓跑拍摄对象呢？您学会像专业人士一样跟踪。

缓慢移动至关重要。这似乎是常识，但在发现一只鸟的兴奋中，很容易冲进去。抵制诱惑。

尝试利用环境对你有利。树木、灌木丛，甚至人造建筑都可以提供掩护，让您可以靠近而不被注意到。但最重要的是要记住。尊重鸟类的空间。

这是一条很好走的路线。您需要足够近才能拍摄到好照片，但又不能太近以免导致鸟儿痛苦。注意你正在入侵的迹象。如果鸟儿看起来很烦躁或发出警告声，请后退。

你最好的选择可能是使用盲板。您需要将其设置在您知道鸟会在的地方，然后等待。这只鸟可能需要几天的时间才能适应。但当它发生时，你将获得一些真正令人惊叹的镜头。在此过程中您不会打扰这只鸟。在我看来，这是双赢。

10.填充框架

想要拍摄鸟类的美丽照片吗？如果您拍摄的是一个人，那么填充画面通常是个好主意。以下是一些好处：

  • 观众很容易将注意力集中在鸟身上
  • 轻松在背景中实现令人愉悦的模糊或散景效果
  • 为鸟儿提供适当的曝光很容易
  • 在现场创作很容易

现在，正如我在第一个技巧中提到的，填充框架并不总是必要的 - 有时，如果您的镜头较短，这是不可能的。但除非您想要拍摄令人惊叹的环境镜头，否则我建议您至少尝试填满画面。采用我上面讨论的低、慢的方法，或者考虑使用盲法。

如果您的镜头很锐利并且使用的是高像素相机，则可以进行一些裁剪，但不要过分依赖这一点；如果你试图将远处的鸟儿变成特写杰作，即使是最好的图像也会开始崩溃。

11.讲一个故事

鸟类摄影中的讲故事不应与书籍和电影中的讲故事相混淆。讲故事是在一张照片中表达一天中的时间、心情、地点或鸟的活动的一种方式，它主要是在场景中加入一些环境（当然，还有一只充满画面的鸟！）。

例如，您可以在鸟旁边添加一些草，您可以拍摄鸟抓鱼的照片，您可以捕捉两只鸟互动的画面，等等。如果您决定拍摄更宽的图像（即，拍摄一只未填充画面的鸟），那么讲故事就变得尤为重要；你的故事必须吸引观众的注意力，因为画面中的小鸟是不够的。

您可以使用以下一些额外技巧来增强故事情节：

  • 通过包括雪、雨或雾来指示天气状况
  • 捕捉日出和日落时的剪影
  • 通过包含盛开的花朵、秋天的颜色或雪来显示季节
  • 包括超现实效果的反射

12. 捕捉动作

一般来说，动作照片胜过栖息照片。如果你能捕捉到一只飞行中的鸟、一只鸟打架或一只鸟抓鱼，观众一定会印象深刻 - 所以我建议你尽可能寻找动作。

当然，与捕捉栖息的鸟类相比，捕捉行动中的鸟类需要更多的努力和耐心。然而，通过一点练习和毅力，您可以成为一名非常有能力的动作鸟类摄影师。

以下是拍摄鸟类时的一些技巧：

  • 在鸟类非常活跃的清晨或下午晚些时候拍摄
  • 等待小鸟移动，然后使用连拍模式一次拍摄多张照片
  • 在按下快门之前跟踪小鸟，直到焦点锁定（确保您使用的是连续对焦！）
  • 通过观察或阅读有关鸟类的内容来学习预测行为

专业提示：当鸟类饥饿时，很容易拍摄它们的动作；它们一心一意地寻找食物时常常会忽略你，但要注意不要打扰它们并保持相当的距离。

顺便说一句，鸟类的动作照片不需要描绘攻击性和/或难以置信的快速运动。您可以简单地拍摄鸟类的有趣行为，就像我为这张牛背鹭照片所做的那样：

13.捕捉飞行中的鸟类

飞行中的鸟类可能是所有鸟类摄影中最受欢迎的主题，但它们也是最困难的。拍摄让观众惊叹的飞行照片并不容易！

您的成功很大程度上取决于鸟儿以及您所采用的技术。较小的鸟类通常在飞行中非常不稳定，并且在画面中很小，这使得它们难以追踪。较大的鸟类速度稍慢，并且不那么难以追踪 - 因此，如果您想成功进行飞行摄影，请从较大、移动速度较慢的鸟类开始。

并确保你经常出去练习，因为清晰的飞行中的鸟照片需要完美的技术。以下是拍摄精彩飞行照片的一些简单技巧：

  • 了解鸟类的飞行模式
  • 了解鸟儿的着陆和起飞模式
  • 如果有不止一只鸟，当其中一只飞翔时，其余的鸟可能会效仿
  • 跟踪小鸟一会儿，让相机在按下快门之前对焦
  • 使用光圈优先，这样您就不必太担心光线条件的变化

14.背景构成画面

在鸟类摄影中，主题很重要，但背景也很重要。当背景干净并与鸟类相得益彰时，鸟类照片看起来很华丽。然而，当背景混乱或分散注意力时，即使鸟本身看起来很棒，拍摄通常也会失败。

底线：在拍摄鸟类照片时留意背景非常重要。以下是您可以遵循的一些简单提示：

  • 避免在背景过于分散注意力的情况下拍摄鸟类照片
  • 避免在背景平淡无趣的情况下拍摄鸟类照片
  • 如果您不喜欢背景，请等待鸟改变位置或调整角度，直到获得有趣的背景
  • 选择最大光圈值以使背景稍微或完全失焦

15. 与普通鸟类一起练习

正如我在整篇文章中反复强调的那样，练习是鸟类摄影的重要组成部分。毕竟，熟能生巧——虽然制作漂亮的鸟类照片并不难，但某些类型的图像（例如飞行中的鸟类）需要一些真正的技巧。

这就是为什么我敦促你练习拍摄更大、更慢、常见的鸟类。我个人的大部分观鸟技巧都是通过海鸥、绿头鸭、鹅和苍鹭学到的。你也可以做到的。

当然，不要害怕走出你的舒适区，拍摄偶尔的鸣禽或滨鸟。但如果你没有拍到漂亮的照片，也不要太激动；相反，专注于掌握您的技术并学习正确的鸟类摄影设置。很快，您就能像专业人士一样拍摄更凶猛的鸟类了！

16.拍摄一些环境鸟类照片

掌握了特写肖像的艺术后，为什么不尝试捕捉环境中的鸟类呢？通常，我们过于关注鸟类本身，以至于忘记了背景——塑造和影响其行为的自然环境。

以一只苍鹭停在沼泽边缘，准备发起攻击为例。捕捉其强烈目光的特写镜头无疑令人惊叹。但是，如果将沼泽的倒影包含在画面中呢？这将苍鹭置于背景中，讲述了它的生活和互动的更完整的故事。

要拍摄迷人的环境鸟类照片，您需要稍微转移焦点。将这只鸟视为更大画面的一部分。在鸟类栖息地中寻找有趣的元素，可以补充您的主题并增加照片的深度。

调整相机设置以确保鸟及其环境都清晰对焦。请记住，较小的光圈会产生更大的景深，使整个场景清晰锐利。

也不要忘记光。利用自然光照亮场景可以使展示鸟类栖息地的效果大不相同。清晨和傍晚是鸟类摄影的黄金时段，让您的场景沐浴在温暖、柔和的光线中。

我承认，在鸟类的环境中捕捉它们可能并不总是能像特写镜头那样立即产生令人惊叹的效果。但请记住，鸟类摄影不仅仅是关于鸟，还关于你想要讲述的故事。环境鸟类照片可能会提供更深刻的叙述，不仅丰富您的作品集，还丰富您作为鸟类摄影师的经验。

17. 看看其他令人惊叹的鸟类摄影

每个学生都需要向大师学习。幸运的是，世界上有很多杰出的鸟类摄影师，研究他们的照片是显着提高自己作品的绝佳方法。

Starting out in bird photography, you may find it difficult to visualize the ideal composition, or maybe you struggle with finding the right lighting. Next, consider joining online bird photography communities. Sites like Flickr or photography-focused Facebook groups are brimming with images and discussions. Not only can you gain inspiration from the images posted, but you can also participate in constructive discussions and critiques.

Finally, don't overlook the power of a deep dive into award-winning bird photographs. They are, after all, award-winning for a reason! Study the photos, learn from them, and try to implement some of the techniques into your own work.

Remember, while it's great to be inspired by others, don't forget to develop your own style. As you progress and learn, you'll start to see patterns in what you like and don't like. This is the beginning of developing your unique style. So go ahead, experiment, deviate, and create.

How to photograph birds: final words

Now that you've finished this article, you're well on your way to capturing beautiful bird photography. Focus your time and energy on learning all the core principles outlined above. Prove to yourself that you have the passion to go out and photograph birds every day (or as often as you can).

Remember that proper techniques will always outperform equipment. Make every attempt to create amazing photographs of the common birds. And enjoy yourself! It's the best-kept secret to success.

        Want to capture the city in a new light? Explore our essential tips for stunning cityscape photography.

        Capturing stunning cityscape photos might seem hard, but it's actually pretty easy – once you know a few tricks, techniques, and secrets.

        In this article, I share my best advice for cityscape photography, including:

        • How to keep your images consistently sharp (even in low light)
        • How to deal with pedestrians in your cityscape scenes
        • How to capture beautiful compositions using foreground elements
        • How to get incredible cityscape night photography
        • Much, much more!

        So if you're ready to capture cityscape images like a pro, then let's dive right in, starting with:

        1. Shoot during the blue hour

        If you want breathtakingly gorgeous cityscape photography, then I recommend you pay careful attention to the light.

        Now, you can create stunning cityscape photos at any time of day (or night) – but if you want the absolute best of the best results, I recommend you head out just after sunset.

        (You can also go out before sunrise, but many photographers struggle to get up early enough!)

        You see, this time is known as the blue hour , and while it's great for all sorts of photography, it's especially amazing for sweeping cityscape shots. During the blue hour, the sky grows darker and the city lights turn on. The balance of light – between the sky and the city – often becomes nearly equal, and you'll witness a stunning combination of tones:

        Working during the blue hour is very rewarding, but you'll need to bring special low-light gear (see my next tip!), and you should also be careful; always tell someone in advance where you plan to be, keep an eye on your surroundings, and carry a phone just in case.

        2. Use a tripod and a remote release for sharp cityscape photos

        If you want to shoot during the blue hour, at night, or even during the golden hours (ie, the hour or two just before sunset and just after sunrise), you'll need to carry two essential pieces of equipment:

        • A sturdy tripod , which will keep your setup supported while shooting.
        • A remote release , which will let you trigger your camera without pressing the shutter button.

        Once the golden hour sets in, the light will start to drop, and you'll need to lengthen your shutter speed if you want to keep your photos well exposed. Unfortunately, longer shutter speeds lead to camera blur – unless you can keep your camera completely still, which is what the tripod and remote release are designed to do!

        Simply mount your camera on the tripod, dial in your preferred shutter speed, then use the remote release – not your finger! – to trigger the shutter. (Pressing the shutter button with your finger will create camera shake, which will blur your images. Resist the urge!)

        One more tip: If you don't want to purchase a remote release, you can always use your camera's self-timer . If your tripod is sturdy and your setup is light, a two-second timer should do the trick.

        3. Bring a wide-angle lens

        It's possible to create stunning cityscape photography with a telephoto lens – you can use it to zoom in and highlight individual buildings and small details – but I'd really recommend you start out with a wide-angle lens. A good wide-angle field of view will let you capture sweeping scenes, and you can even combine foreground and background layers for a three-dimensional effect:

        What type of wide-angle lens is best? Beginners should try out a 24mm prime lens, which will cost very little yet still offer a wide field of view (and crisp optics). If you're willing to spend more and you want extra flexibility, a 16-35mm lens is a good bet; it'll let you capture various wide perspectives as you zoom from the ultra-wide 16mm to the tighter 35mm.

        4. Incorporate leading lines into your compositions

        Beginners often point their camera directly at city skylines and fire away – but while there's nothing wrong with such an approach, it can get repetitive after a while, plus the images tend to look flat .

        On the other hand, if you can incorporate a foreground line (or three!) that leads the eye into the image and toward key background elements, your shots will have tons of three-dimensionality. They'll also be far more interesting, as they'll take the viewer's eye on a journey from foreground to background. Check out this next image, which uses a path to lead the eye toward the mysterious light in the background:

        I'd also mention that leading lines can help create order in an otherwise chaotic scene. If you're shooting in an area with lots of pedestrians or cars, for instance, a nice leading line – such as a road – can cut through the confusion and help bring the composition together.

        5. Seek out reflections

        Start with reflections. They're everywhere in a city; you just have to know where to look! Buildings, water, and cars – they all offer ample opportunities for capturing compelling reflections, which can add intrigue and depth to your photos.

        Note that reflections can be large and highly visible, such as the golden hues of a sunset mirrored in a row of sleek, glass buildings. Or they can be more subtle, like the fleeting image of a passerby's face reflected in the glossy hood of a car. Play with this as you capture your cityscape photos and see what you can create!

        Also, tweak your angle and adjust your focal length. Play around until you get that perfect reflection, the one that transforms a mundane scene into something magical. And remember, don't shy away from getting low. Crouching down near a puddle can result in a surprisingly disorienting image, one that casts back the world in a new, unexpected light.

        6. Shoot long exposures at intersections

        Do you want to capture cityscape photos like this next example?

        The good news is that it's not as hard as you might think, and it doesn't require any Photoshop wizardry, either!

        Simply find a busy intersection in a city, and get up high . You can shoot from an observation deck, a roof, or a parking garage; just make sure you have an unobstructed view of the high-traffic areas.

        Bring a tripod, bring your remote release, and capture some long-exposure shots . I'd recommend using a shutter speed of at least five seconds, but you may wish to shoot for longer depending on the speed of the traffic. The goal is to keep the shutter speed long enough to blur the cars into lines of light.

        (Pro tip: Make sure that your scene features some curves. Traffic moving in a straight line can look okay if you include interesting structures in the composition, but if you're focusing on the roadways from above, I highly recommend you include some bends and corners.)

        7. Look for fountains

        I love fountains in cityscape photography. They look great when incorporated into long-exposure shots – the water will turn into a beautiful blur – and they're also just stunning points of interest to add to your compositions.

        Happily, most cities are full of fountains. If you're not sure where to find a fountain or two at your next cityscape destination, pull up Google Maps and do a quick search.

        Then, when you're out shooting, look for ways to include the fountains in your compositions. For instance, you can use the water to frame buildings, like this:

        Or you can use fountains as interesting foreground subjects to add three-dimensionality to your images.

        8. Shoot the city skyline

        Yes, the city against the sky – photographed from a great distance – is a classic shot. Yet it's one that never loses its charm. The unique silhouette of a city, etched against the clouds or a pale blue sky, can make for the kind of photo that you want to hang on your wall.

        But how do you get the best results? Look for a vantage point that lets you capture the skyline from a distance. A spot across the water works great, especially if you're photographing in a city with larger waterways. But keep in mind that the city skyline is a popular subject. Your challenge is to capture it in a way that's unique, one that showcases your individual style.

        Why not experiment with an ultra-long exposure? Or wait for a foggy day when the city becomes an ethereal dream? Don't forget the magic of beautiful light, either. Shooting at sunrise or sunset can bathe the city in warm hues and create an unforgettable image.

        9. Use patterns to improve your cityscape compositions

        If you're after more subtle cityscape photography, you don't need to capture stunning vistas of skyscrapers at night; instead, take a walk during the day, observe simple city scenes, and look for patterns.

        You see, patterns have the ability to bring a sense of visual rhythm and harmony to an image. And when you incorporate them into the overall scene – here, a wide-angle lens is a big help! – you can create a calming, even meditative image.

        Look at how the two patterns, made of the trees and the pedestrians, elevates this shot:

        And by the way: Most scenes feature patterns of some kind, even if they're not immediately apparent. So if you're drawn to a scene but you can't find a pattern, stop, take a deep breath, and look around. I'm guessing you'll be able to find some repeating graphic elements, such as shapes, lines, or even colors.

        When you do, include them in your composition, and let them add interest to – or even unite – the overall scene.

        10. Use symmetry for bold cityscape images

        Ever felt that tingling sense of satisfaction when you see something perfectly balanced? Symmetry can bring that feeling into your cityscape photography.

        It's easy to shy away from symmetry, to think it clashes with other so-called “rules” of composition, like the rule of thirds. But when wielded with intention, symmetry can add intensity and visual appeal to your shots.

        Take buildings, for example. These concrete structures are often innately symmetrical. Imagine standing dead-center, looking straight up at a skyscraper. There's a stark, beautiful symmetry there, and a shot captured from that perspective can look breathtaking.

        Don't avoid symmetry, embrace it. Make it your own. Challenge the conventions and remember that rules in photography are more like guidelines, made to be bent and sometimes broken.

        11. Try frame-within-a-frame compositional techniques

        The city environment is brimming with opportunities to experiment with composition, and one method that's always interesting to play around with is the frame-within-a-frame technique.

        The idea is straightforward enough: You choose a primary subject and then frame it using another scene element, typically in the foreground. Archways, door frames, even gaps between buildings – these can all act as your “frame.”

        Now, there are a few things to keep in mind here. First, picking the right aperture – and hence controlling the depth of field in your image – is essential. This is because you want your foreground frame and your main subject to both be in sharp focus.

        Finding the right frame can be challenging when you're starting out. You might look around and feel there's nothing that will work. But remember, the frame doesn't have to completely surround your subject. Even something that partially frames your subject can add depth and draw the viewer's eye.

        You could also think about the nature of your frame. Is it something rigid and man-made, like a window or a bridge? Or is it something more natural and fluid, like tree branches or reflections? This contrast between the frame and the main subject can make your photo even more intriguing.

        Sometimes, a well-placed frame can dramatically alter the narrative of your photo. A busy street, when viewed through a quiet café window, takes on a different tone. It can emphasize the dichotomy of public and private spaces, the calm amidst the chaos – plus it can just be very eye-catching!

        12. Use long shutter speeds to blur pedestrians

        Many beginner cityscape photographers struggle to deal with pedestrians. After all, if you like the surrounding scene, you may view pedestrians as a distraction.

        And it's true: Pedestrians can be a distraction when rendered in sharp detail.

        But if you lengthen your shutter speed to 1/5s and beyond, pedestrians will blur . They'll begin to lose detail, and they'll appear as an interesting ghostly presence:

        Note that you can always experiment with different shutter speeds here, and your results will vary depending on the speed of the pedestrians.

        Pro tip: If you want to blur pedestrians but you're shooting in bright light, I'd recommend mounting a neutral density filter in front of your lens, which will block light from the sensor and prevent overexposure.

        13. Capture the intimate details

        Now let's shift gears a bit. Cityscape photography isn't just about capturing wide, sweeping shots. Just as landscape photographers occasionally focus on tiny details within a larger vista, you can do the same in the city.

        Turn your lens to details that strike you as moving or powerful. Get up close and capture them. A weathered door. A vibrant graffiti. A pigeon perched on a windowsill. They all have a story to tell.

        Textures can be incredibly striking, too. The sleek glass of skyscrapers. The rough brickwork of older buildings. The faded flyers plastered on utility poles. The crushed soda can on the sidewalk. These details, though often overlooked, can provide an intimate view of city life.

        Remember, it's not just about what the items are, but how they contribute to your composition. The play of light and shadow. The interesting shapes and forms. The textures and colors. The contrasts and harmonies. Arrange all these elements as if you're creating an abstract shot out of shapes; that way, you can create a compelling composition that also speaks to the nature of the city.

        14. If you can't use a tripod, then improvise

        While tripods are allowed in most places, certain areas – such as city parks, business plazas, and city observation decks – may have a “no tripod” rule. (Alternatively, they may require you to pay to bring in a tripod; it's up to you to decide whether this is worth the money.)

        Before heading to a new location, I recommend you call ahead to find out whether tripods are allowed. And if they aren't , don't give up; just be prepared to do your best with what you have.

        For instance, you might bring a hard-shelled backpack, or look for tables, pillars, benches, and anything else on location that is flat and safe.

        Then position your camera stably and safely, and use a remote release or self-timer to trigger the shutter. While you won't have the same level of compositional flexibility offered by an actual tripod, you can still get great results, even at night:

        15. Don't be afraid to shoot in bad weather

        Many photographers stay indoors during bad weather, but stormy skies, rain, and snow can offer plenty of cityscape photography opportunities.

        For instance, a foreboding sky might act as a moody backdrop to a skyscraper, while snow will create plenty of atmosphere as it falls around city buildings.

        Personally, I like photographing during and after rain, as the moisture causes the city streets and buildings to glow (especially at blue hour):

        But if you want to capture beautiful cityscape photos in rough weather, you must take steps to keep your equipment (and you!) safe. Use a waterproof cover to protect your camera and lens, and never change lenses out in the open. Also, be sure to wear a coat of your own, and if things get really bad – for instance, you see lightning – then head inside. No shot is worth jeopardizing your safety!

        16. Combine water and buildings

        Here's a secret I've discovered over the years of cityscape photography: Cities often have water bodies, be it rivers, lakes, or bays, and these can be a powerful addition to the drama of your shots. These bodies of water can serve as a beautiful foreground that draws your viewer's eyes into the image.

        It's like adding an extra layer of depth and interest to your photo. Think about the possibilities! You can show water reflecting city lights, the contrast of a relatively still surface against bustling city life, or even capture long-exposure water images to create a misty, dream-like aesthetic.

        我的建议？ Seek compositions that include water and city structures. Return to the same location under varying conditions.

        A sunny day will give you crisp, well-lit shots. On an overcast day, you might catch the city in a more introspective mood. Early mornings can reveal a city waking up, the first rays of sun glinting off the water.

        Mix it up.实验。 You'll be amazed at how the same spot can yield such diverse results.

        17. Use HDR as needed

        Cityscape photography often involves capturing contrasting elements, such as dark buildings against brighter skies or radiant electric lights adorning buildings at night. These scenarios can be tough to successfully expose as it's challenging to maintain detail in both the highlights and the shadows within a single frame.

        Enter HDR, or high dynamic range imaging. It's a technique that can be a big help when faced with such challenges, and while it can be a bit advanced, the results are often worth it.

        HDR involves capturing multiple shots at different exposures: One for the bright sky, one for the darker buildings, and so on. Later, you can blend together these shots to create a final image that retains detail across the entire dynamic range of the scene.

        Yes, HDR might seem intimidating at first. It requires patience and a bit of technical know-how. But trust me, with a little practice and a reliable tripod to keep your frames consistent, HDR will elevate your cityscape photography to new heights.

        Cityscape photography tips: final words

        You've just taken a deep dive into the world of cityscape photography, unraveled its mysteries, and gained invaluable insights. In this journey, you've learned to view the city realm with a fresh, artistic perspective.

        Perfecting cityscape photography may seem like a towering task, akin to scaling the tallest skyscrapers. But remember, every professional once stood where you are now! With the tips and techniques outlined in this article, you're well-equipped to reach those heights and capture those breathtaking images you've always dreamed of.

        你还在等什么？ Grab your camera, hit the streets, and let your creativity loose. With every click, you'll see progress. Remember, every city has a story waiting to be told, and now you have the skills to tell it beautifully. Happy shooting!

        让我们开始吧！

        1. 仔细设置您的平板电脑

        您的第一笔生意是？以正确的方式设置您的绘图板。

        虽然许多设备都具有即插即用功能，并且似乎只要插入即可工作，但对于图形平板电脑来说，这并不是全部。

        说实话，您也许可以使用笔，但只有安装和配置必要的软件后，平板电脑的全部功能才会解锁。确保为您的平板电脑安装所有相关驱动程序，如果它附带软件套件，请探索所有选项以根据您的喜好对其进行优化。

        您的平板电脑可能看起来在没有任何软件的情况下功能齐全，但请相信我：如果您不想错过任何功能，安装提供的软件至关重要。

        随着时间的推移，您的偏好可能会发生变化。如果您觉得有什么可以改进的地方，请重新进入软件设置。只需点击几下即可解决您的问题。

        2. 对快捷按钮进行编程

        完成基本设置后，就可以将注意力转向快捷按钮了。

        绘图板上的可编程按钮数量可能因型号而异。经济实惠的可能只有几个，而价格较高的可能布满了按钮。

        如何自定义这些按钮完全取决于您。一个明智的方法是反思您通常的照片编辑工作流程。您执行最多的操作是什么？只需单击一下按钮即可更方便地执行其中哪一个？

        一旦您弄清楚了这一点，设置按钮以满足您的喜好就轻而易举了。

        请记住，您可以完全控制快捷按钮配置。让它们为你工作，而不是相反。

        老实说，我发现自己并不经常使用快捷按钮。我发现唯一方便的是旋转画布。你可能也有同样的感觉，那完全没问题。不要因为使用不符合您的风格或需求的东西而感到有压力。

        3.学习键盘快捷键

        即使您拥有图形输入板，键盘仍然是犯罪的重要伙伴，尤其是当您想通过快速键盘快捷键加快工作流程时。请务必仔细阅读您最喜欢的编辑程序提供的每一个快捷方式，写下最有用的快捷方式，并最好将它们牢记在心。

        您可能想知道：如果您有一个用于照片编辑的绘图板，并且具有一些可编程按钮，那么为什么还需要键盘快捷键呢？

        无论您使用 Lightroom、Photoshop 还是其他编辑软件，功能都非常丰富，不可能将所有功能映射到几个按钮上。这就是为什么值得您花时间编写一些按钮，然后花时间学习尽可能多的键盘快捷键 - 特别是那些与您通常的编辑工作流程一致的键盘快捷键。

        不可否认，一开始使用手写笔并用另一只手点击键盘快捷键可能看起来有点奇怪。但要勇往直前，坚持下去；你很快就会发现它并不像乍看起来那么令人畏惧。

        4.了解“撤消”的魔力

        在您可以使用的所有键盘快捷键中，有一个您可能比其他任何快捷键都更依赖。这就是“撤消”功能，可以撤消您的上一个操作，可以通过按 Ctrl+z（或 Cmd+z）来访问

        钢笔可以让你做出精确的笔画，但就像素描一样，并不是每一个笔画都能在第一次就完全按照你想要的方式进行。反复点击“撤消”直到达到您想要的结果绝对没有坏处。因此，请熟悉 Ctrl+z（或 Cmd+z）和 Ctrl+Alt+z（或 Cmd+Alt+z）快捷键。

        如果它让您的生活更轻松，您甚至可以将此功能设置为平板电脑上的快捷按钮。

        5. 自定义画笔设置

        当您将绘图板带入照片编辑之旅时，您还可以解锁 Photoshop 中以前禁止使用的一些实用功能。

        画笔设置——更具体地说，笔压力设置——可以说是其中最有影响力的。通过激活这些功能，您只需改变按下平板电脑的力度即可控制画笔压力。

        例如，如果您选择了“始终使用压力调整大小”选项，则画笔大小将根据您用笔施加的力而变化。

        如果您使用不透明度选项，轻轻一触就会产生低不透明度的笔触。激活这两个设置，效果会变得更加复杂。

        在我看来，掌握压力设置是使用绘图板进行照片编辑的最强大优势之一。事实上，如果您仍然不确定的话，这些设置为使用平板电脑提供了一个令人信服的案例。我的建议？熟悉这些设置 - 它们将塑造您的图形输入板编辑体验。

        6.尝试倾斜刷子

        如果您发现自己很少使用倾斜敏感笔刷进行照片修饰，请不要感到惊讶。但是，嘿，他们就在那里，为什么不认识一下他们呢？您不想意外地偶然发现这些工具并怀疑您的平板电脑出现故障。

        7.探索数字艺术教程

        使用绘图板进行修饰可能会让人感觉既直观又令人困惑地违反直觉。如果您有一些艺术经验，您可能会发现更容易适应。但如果你像我一样——零艺术背景——帮自己一个忙，花一些时间观看数字绘画教程。

        • 绘制线条：这些练习旨在掌握对触控笔的控制并熟悉平板电脑的压力灵敏度。它们将帮助您做出更精确的动作，最终提高输出的质量。观看这些教程并练习画线将增强您使用平板电脑的信心和体验。
        • 渲染：专注于使用值进行绘画的数字绘画教程非常有用，特别是当您想要应用闪避和加深等技术时。这些方法将提高您的混合技巧并鼓励更多受控的调整。

        8. 使用绘图板手写笔进行练习

        您已经看过教程了。伟大的！现在，是时候卷起袖子，亲自动手了。

        设置空白画布并使用不同的压力设置处理这些笔触。这是快速掌握平板电脑的关键。

        同样，练习混合值也很重要，特别是如果您计划将某些修饰技术纳入您的工作流程中。无论是在修饰范围之内还是之外，都要坚持不懈地练习。

        底线：不要仅仅停留在观看教程上。热切地练习，并定期回顾这些练习。定期练习是您熟练使用平板电脑的黄金门票。

        9. 开始前热身

        这个完全是可选的，但如果你感觉僵硬并且没有得到你想要的结果，你可以借用传统艺术家的另一种技术并做一些热身练习。

        你在这里不需要任何花哨的东西。只需启动 Photoshop，打开空白画布，然后花几分钟（比如两到三分钟）磨练您的线条工作和渲染，或者您计划在编辑过程中使用的任何其他技能。简单而有效！

        10. 练习，练习，练习！

        如何真正掌握您的绘图板？答案由来已久：练习！然后再练习一些。

        生活中的每项技能都需要重复和耐心，使用绘图板也不例外。使用得越多，效果就越好。所以不要退缩。潜入并开始积累这些时间。您早期遇到的打嗝很快就会成为过去。

        用引导线加强你的摄影游戏。掌握引导观众眼球并创作迷人照片的艺术。

        摄影中的主导线是什么？它们如何改善你的构图？

        在本文中，您将发现有关引导线所需了解的所有信息，包括：

        • 为什么每个摄影师都应该学习如何使用引导线（提示：它们可以大大增加照片的影响力）
        • 有很多容易寻找引导线的地方
        • 如何使用线条创作美丽的三维图像
        • 多得多！

        因此，如果您准备好成为专家，那么让我们开始吧！

        摄影中的主导线是什么？

        引导线是指将观看者的眼睛从构图的一个部分引导到另一部分的线条。通常，这些线条从画面底部开始，引导眼睛向上，从图像的前景到背景。

        当用作构图技术时，引导线通常会移向照片的主要主题。例如，一条河流可能会引导人们的眼睛看到背景中一座被雾气覆盖的山，或者一根圆木可能会引导人们的眼睛看到令人惊叹的日落。

        请注意，引导线可以是任何东西：河流或原木，如上面的示例中提到的，但也可以是道路上的标记、海滩上的尖石、沙子上的线条、房屋的墙壁 - 如果它看起来像一条线并且能够引导观看者的眼睛，那么它可以用作引导线！

        要考虑的引导线类型

        您可能会将引导线视为摄影工具箱中的一个整体工具。然而，它们的用途远比您想象的要多，并且可以以各种形式出现。

        例如，我们可以根据这些线的方向来识别它们：垂直、水平或对角线。垂直引导线从框架底部向顶部延伸。这种方法增加了深度，因为线条邀请观众踏上场景之旅。水平线从画面的一侧移动到另一侧，增加了强度，而对角线则引入了动态运动。

        引导线也不限于直线。尽管直线更常见，但不要低估曲线的视觉吸引力。想象一下海滩上卷曲的波浪或向观察者伸展的下垂的树枝。底线：两种线条都有其独特的魅力，曲线提供了直线很少能达到的流动感和优雅感。

        为什么引导线很重要？

        引导线引导观众浏览构图。

        因此，通过在画面中仔细放置引导线，您可以将注意力吸引到照片中重要的区域，例如美丽的山脉或海上的日落。换句话说，您可以使用引导线让观看者看到您希望他们看到的地方，并避开您希望他们避开的区域。

        您还可以使用引导线在整个构图中创建流动（通常称为动态） 。引导线自然地带领观看者围绕照片进行旅程，这让他们保持参与（总是一件好事！）。

        另外，引导线是在图像中创建三维（即深度）的好方法。通过强调线条的起点，然后让它消失在背景中，您可以创造出在风景摄影中看起来令人难以置信的3D 幻觉。

        如何使用引导线：基础知识

        使用引导线需要两个简单的步骤：

        1. 找到引导线
        2. 将引导线融入到你的作文中

        当然，说起来容易做起来难，但上述步骤实际上并不困难；他们只需要一点毅力。让我们依次看看每个步骤。

        第 1 步：找到引导线

        无论您住在哪里，无论您喜欢在哪里拍照......

        ……引导线无处不在。

        这可能看起来不太可能，但确实如此。毕竟，请记住引导线只是线条，而且存在很多这样的线条，对吧？关键是找到它们（并将它们创造性地融入到你的作品中，正如我在下一节中讨论的那样）。

        那么，具体来说，您应该在哪里寻找引导线呢？

        就我个人而言，我认为最好的起点是一条路径；路径本质上是领先的，因为它们会到达某个地方，并且路径边缘通常会在地平线上创建一个消失点（两条或多条线在理论上无穷远处汇聚的地方）。另外，您可以在任何地方找到路径——森林、公园、城市，甚至乡村（道路也算路径！）。

        但您也可以找到许多其他引导线。虽然摄影师在他们的构图中当然会使用路径，但他们也会使用沙子、倒下的原木、一束鲜花、有趣的岩石、桥梁、栅栏等中的图案。以下是需要考虑的事项的完整列表：

        • 道路
        • 栅栏
        • 木板路
        • 桥梁
        • 砖块
        • 任何连续的东西，例如灯柱
        • 建筑物
        • 门口
        • 窗玻璃
        • 河流
        • 海岸线
        • 波浪
        • 沙丘
        • 树
        • 高草
        • 悬崖
        • 岩石

        当然，这个清单并不详尽。总有更多的线索等待被发现！因此，下次设置镜头时，请花点时间检查场景中是否有突出的线条。即使需要进行一些搜索，您也一定会找到一些好的。

        第 2 步：将引导线纳入您的作文中

        所以你已经找到了一两条引导线。干得好——但工作还没有完成！现在是时候将引导线真正融入到你的构图中了，这是一个深思熟虑、深思熟虑的过程。

        首先，问问自己：我希望这条引导线将观众带到哪里？通常，答案会涉及背景中的有趣特征（例如日落），因此您需要调整相机位置，直到引导线大致指向正确的方向。

        （如果引导线没有到达您想要的位置，您可以尝试沿着该线前后或左右移动，或者您可以找到另一条在构图中效果更好的引导线。远离主要主题的引导线可能会适得其反。）

        接下来，问问自己：引导线是否足够有趣，可以作为前景主题？我可以靠得足够近以使其在画面中变大吗？

        如果你的引导线很有趣并且你知道你可以接近，那就这样做。最好的照片通常包含一条强有力的引导线，将观看者吸引到前景，然后将他们从前景引导到背景，就像下面照片中的石头一样：

        当然，有些引导线无法吸引观众的注意力，或者难以接近，但这没关系 - 引导线总是很有力量，即使它们不是引人注目的。您仍然可以使用它们，但请确保找到一个吸引眼球的有趣的前景主题，或者真正收紧您的构图以专注于主要主题。

        最后，一旦您大致定位了主题和任何引导线，请再次评估场景。考虑一下可以增强引导线效果的方法，也许可以通过改变相机位置、降低或升高，甚至使用更宽或更长的焦距。

        那就出手吧！

        使用引导线的提示和技巧

        现在您已经熟悉了基础知识，让我们讨论一些使用引导线改进构图的技巧，首先：

        1. 使用可用的最广角镜头

        您不需要广角镜头来创作令人惊叹的引导线构图。

        但这确实非常有帮助。

        为什么？好吧，广角镜头可以让你捕捉广阔的场景——这样你就可以将引导线定位在画面底部，然后让它们流入镜头，慢慢地越来越远，直到它们消失（或到达你的主要拍摄对象）。

        将此与长焦构图进行比较，其中引导线通常从靠近主体的位置开始，然后快速终止。缺乏活力、缺乏趣味性、缺乏三维度。

        正是出于这个原因，许多风景摄影师都使用超广角焦距进行拍摄。他们经常找到一条引导线，使用广角镜头来强调它，并创造出令人惊叹的深度构图。

        合理？

        2. 不要害怕将多条引导线合并到一个作品中

        一条引导线很好，但如果你能找到多条引导线，所有引导线都引导观众走向你的主要主题，你的构图就会非常强大。

        例如，您可以使用道路的两侧来指向远处的山。或者，您可以在沙子上使用两条线——一条从右下角开始，一条从左下角开始——指向蓝色的海洋。

        请注意，所有引导线应尽可能指向主题。如果线条偏离你的主题，它们就会引导观众走向错误的方向，这将阻止他们充分欣赏图像。让两条或多条线向你的主题汇聚可能需要一些创造力，但最终的结果是值得的。

        3. 使用远近技巧创造足够的深度

        近远技术在风景摄影中尤其常见。这是一种在照片中创造大量深度的简单方法，您也可以通过它来拍摄像这样的强大照片：

        使用起来也非常简单。这就是你要做的：

        首先，确保你的引导线足够引人注目。它本身应该成为一个主题——就像一块有趣的岩石或一片五颜六色的花朵。

        其次，确保使用宽焦距。我建议至少使用 35 毫米（在全画幅相机上），但 24 毫米、18 毫米甚至 14 毫米更好。

        第三，将相机安装在三脚架上，并降低到拍摄对象的上方。您希望引导线在画面中突出，即使这意味着距离拍摄对象只有几英寸。您需要调小光圈，例如 f/8、f/11，甚至 f/16，以保持前景和背景清晰。

        你的最终镜头将看起来令人难以置信——有一个有趣的前景主题，一条引导眼睛的线条，再加上（希望如此！）一个有趣的背景主题来完成构图。

        4.拥抱S曲线

        S 曲线是风景摄影师中流行的工具，它当然不是一般的引导线；这是一条蜿蜒的小路，以迷人的 S 形远离镜头。它受到人们喜爱是有原因的：它为图像增添了深刻的深度感和活力。

        如果你足够仔细的话，你可以在大自然中找到这些优美的曲线，尤其是在河流中。如果您一直在寻找但尚未确定可在您的作品中使用的 S 曲线，那么您就需要发挥创意了。也许沙滩上有脚印，或者秋天有一些树叶。不管是什么，诀窍是用广角镜头靠近以强调曲线。

        此外，曲线在构图中的位置也至关重要。常见的做法是将 S 曲线放置在画面的中心，引导观看者的眼睛看向远处引人注目的元素，例如山脉或瀑布。但请随意尝试并找到最适合您的方法。

        5.研究其他摄影师的作品

        这是真正深入研究引导线力量的好方法吗？查看您最喜欢的射手的作品。

        几乎每个摄影师在其职业生涯的某个阶段都会利用主导线，而真正伟大的摄影师善于利用它们将平凡变成非凡。首先，挑选一些您最喜欢的照片，并研究摄影师如何使用引导线来创作引人注目的构图。

        引导线放置在哪里？它们是垂直的，向天空延伸，还是水平的，横跨整个框架？也许它们是对角排列的，增加了一种运动感？或者它们是弯曲的，为图像增加了一层额外的复杂性？这里的目的是向工艺大师学习，并培养自己对强大引导线的洞察力。

        当您在自己的摄影中遇到类似情况时，请使用这些见解来指导您的方法。随着时间的推移，您将开始在各处看到引导线，并且有效地使用它们将成为第二天性。

        如何使用引导线获得更好的构图：最后的话

        引导线是引导我们的视线浏览照片的关键构图元素。它们可用于讲述故事、强调重点以及在两个对象之间建立联系。

        因此，无论您走到哪里，都开始考虑引导线。练习在日常生活的混乱中找到引导线。你的作品将会变得非常好、非常快！

        无反光镜相机配有电子取景器（EVF）。当您将无反光镜相机放在您的眼前时，您看到的是一个非常小的屏幕。这会向您显示按下快门按钮时相机将记录的内容。

        但电子取景器实际上是如何工作的呢？ EVF 适合您吗？在本文中，我将探讨 EVF 的详细情况，包括其独特的优势和特性。

        请注意，本文并不是要争论电子取景器与光学取景器。相反，我的目标是帮助您了解什么是 EVF，以便您确定它们是否适合您的需求。

        让我们开始吧！

        什么是电子取景器？

        电子取景器 (EVF) 通常是无反光镜相机内的 LCD 或 OLED 屏幕。当相机的传感器记录通过镜头的视图时，该图像会实时显示在取景器内的屏幕上。

        请注意，电子取景器与数码单反相机提供的取景器（称为光学取景器）形成对比。当您通过数码单反相机上的取景器观看时，您实际上是在通过镜头观看，或者更准确地说，是通过一系列镜子将镜头中的光线反射到您的眼睛中。

        由于无反光镜相机中没有镜子阻挡传感器，因此 EVF 在相机开机的整个过程中都会捕获图像。它们提供从相机传感器到摄影师眼睛的持续反馈，包括（如果需要）精确的曝光模拟。

        由于电子取景器本质上是计算机显示器，因此它们可以显示的不仅仅是通过镜头进行的简单预览。 EVF 通常允许您查看有用的叠加层，例如直方图和手动对焦指南，以及不同的相机配置文件（黑白、鲜艳、高对比度等）。 They can also be used to view the scene at high magnifications and review images that have already been captured.

        Electronic viewfinder advantages

        Ever pondered the perks of using a camera with an electronic viewfinder? Well, there's a host of them! Especially for budding photographers, these high-tech features can streamline tricky processes like setting exposure and focus.

        Let's delve into these advantages:


        Advantage #1: An electronic viewfinder offers easier manual exposure control

        Manual exposure can be a tough nut to crack. Deciphering the exposure meter, calculating adjustments, grasping how light bounces off varying surfaces and hues – it's a lot for a newcomer. So the natural fallback is the handy Auto mode.

        An electronic viewfinder, though, simplifies manual exposure control because it's visual. With a mirrorless camera, what you behold in the viewfinder is a fair preview of your shot. The moment you tweak your exposure controls, the viewfinder reflects those changes. It's like getting a sneak peek into your shot before you press the shutter button. Thus, mastering manual exposure becomes a breeze.

        但有一个问题。 On certain cameras, you might need to tweak settings so the electronic viewfinder reflects exposure alterations. This is crucial if the viewfinder's brightness level stays put despite changes in exposure.

        Additionally, before you head out and start shooting with an EVF-laden mirrorless camera, make sure your viewfinder's brightness is neutral. If the screen is too dim or too bright, it can lead to overexposed or underexposed shots. However, don't fret over slight discrepancies. Modern cameras come packed with high-dynamic-range sensors that can compensate for minor differences.

        Advantage #2: EVFs offer advanced focus information

        When I peer into my DSLR camera's viewfinder, I see a tiny illuminated spot indicating the image is focused. But with my mirrorless camera's electronic viewfinder, I'm privy to much more focus detail.

        Each camera brand has its own unique way of highlighting the focused area. My Lumix camera, for example, displays a light blue overlay on the sharply focused regions.

        This comes in super handy when you're using a multipoint autofocus option. You see, cameras don't always focus on the desired area. But a quick look at the focus details in your electronic viewfinder gives you a clear picture of what's in focus.

        Advantage #3: An electronic viewfinder displays in-camera edits

        Most cameras come loaded with various profile modes, like monochrome, portrait, or vivid, to jazz up your photos as you shoot them. Here's where an electronic viewfinder steals the show – it previews the chosen scene mode effect even before you click the photo.

        Imagine you're learning to capture the world in black and white. With an electronic viewfinder, you can set it to grayscale, letting you see your composition in monochrome. No more guessing games on how the final shot would look – you can see it in real-time through your viewfinder.

        Advantage #4: You can use an EVF to review images with clarity

        Your electronic viewfinder isn't just for taking photos; you can use it to review images stored on your memory card. Sometimes, it's crucial to review an image, especially if you're unsure about your exposure settings.

        Photographers often use the camera's monitor for this, but that could be problematic in bright sunlight. Glare reflecting off the monitor can diminish the clarity of your photos. But with your electronic viewfinder, you can review your photos without the distraction of reflected light, giving you a more accurate impression of your work.

        A note about electronic viewfinder quality

        Electronic viewfinders are a bit like people – no two are exactly alike. You'll see variations in resolution from camera model to camera model, and even across different manufacturers.

        This might sound technical, but here's the simple takeaway: the higher the viewfinder's resolution, the crisper your image will look. Just like with smartphones and TVs, this is a technology that's advancing rapidly. With every new mirrorless camera that hits the shelves, we're seeing viewfinders that pack in more detail than ever before.

        Don't forget to consider the difference between LCD and OLED viewfinders, too. As a rule of thumb, OLEDs are generally brighter and render colors more realistically.

        Electronic viewfinders in photography: final words

        Switching from a DSLR's optical viewfinder to an electronic one can feel a little like learning to ride a bike all over again. It requires a bit of a mental shift, sure, but trust me, it's worth it. The benefits far outweigh the initial discomfort.

        One of the biggest perks, especially if you're just getting the hang of manual mode, is being able to see the effect of your adjustments in real time. Tweak the aperture, dial in a different shutter speed, mix up the ISO settings – and you'll see the result right in your viewfinder. For those of us who are visual learners (and let's face it, most photographers are), this is a game-changer. It's much more intuitive than trying to decipher a camera's exposure meter.

        Believe me when I say that an electronic viewfinder can make photography even more enjoyable! They simplify some of the technical aspects of shooting, which means you can focus more on capturing the scene in front of you.

        Finally, don't worry too much about comparing electronic and optical viewfinders. They both have their strong points, and I frequently use both in my own work, so you certainly shouldn't stress over the difference.

        Looking to delve into forest photography? Capture the intimate beauty of woodlands with these expert techniques.

        Forests, with their enchanting light, varied geometry, and tranquil aura, beckon to both amateur and professional photographers alike.

        But here's the deal: If you've ever tried to snap a forest photo, you may have realized it's not as simple as just hitting the shutter button. You can easily get lost in the chaos of branches, shadows, and foliage. Not to mention grappling with the challenge of different lighting conditions and appropriate settings that can vary dramatically depending on the situation.

        That's where this guide comes in. I'll break down the essentials of forest photography, provide useful gear recommendations, share the ideal settings, and throw in some handy tips to help you elevate your forest photography game. By the end, you'll be armed with practical knowledge and creative strategies to transform your photos from average to awe-inspiring – making your next woodland adventure a photographic triumph.

        让我们开始吧。

        What is forest photography?

        Ever looked at the array of trees in a woodland area and seen an opportunity to capture an amazing shot? That's the essence of forest photography. It's a broad field that covers any photography centered around woodlands. Whether it's the deciduous forests of North America, the boreal forests of Siberia, or the jungles of the Amazon, they all fall under the scope of forest photography.

        It's more than just capturing a stand of trees. Yes, you can create a landscape shot with dozens of trees leading into the distance, but you might also focus on the detailed texture of bark or the delicate flowers on the forest floor. Forest photography is a versatile niche. You aren't limited to one approach; there are plenty of options available for your creative exploration.

        Typically, forest photography is seen as a subset of landscape photography. However, its expansive nature means it can venture into the domains of macro photography – close-ups of leaves, for example – and wildlife photography, capturing the dynamic movement of a deer among the tree trunks. So, if you're drawn to forest photography, there's no need to feel restricted. The forest is a vibrant, diverse canvas just waiting for your creativity.

        What makes forest photography special?

        Simply put, forests are amazing photographic subjects. They offer endless opportunities for photographers to play with geometry, contrasting the vertical lines of tree trunks with the horizontal planes of the forest floor.

        Photographing forests, however, isn't just about the natural lines and shapes they provide. It's also about the challenge of creating order from the inherent messiness of woodlands. A forest scene can be complex, chaotic even. Organizing such a scene into a cohesive frame presents an exciting puzzle for any photographer.

        Another allure of forest photography is its tranquility. Forests are peaceful spaces, serene and quiet. It's this tranquility you get to capture in your images – and the act of walking through the forest with your camera, immersed in the calm and silence, is an experience that's therapeutic in itself.

        The best gear for forest photography

        While you can capture great forest photos with any equipment, there are a few items that'll help you get high-quality forest images on a consistent basis.

        A tripod

        A sturdy landscape photography tripod is essential for any woodland photography; forest environments tend to be dark, and without a sturdy support system for your camera, you'll be forced to widen your aperture (and sacrifice depth of field ) or drop your shutter speed until you can no longer get sharp shots.

        A full-frame camera

        Second, while your camera choice isn't critical – in fact, you can capture great forest shots with pretty much any model, including a smartphone – I do encourage you to use a DSLR or a mirrorless camera, ideally one with a decent megapixel count and a larger (preferably full-frame) sensor. More megapixels offer greater flexibility when printing or cropping, while a larger sensor will enhance your abilities to capture high dynamic range scenes in a single shot.

        If you can't afford a full-frame camera, however, don't sweat it. Today's APS-C and MFT models produce outstanding images (and they're more compact, too, which is a major bonus).

        A variety of lenses

        Next, if you do go with an interchangeable lens mirrorless model or DSLR, you'll want to carry a few lenses. A wide-angle prime or zoom will help you capture scenic-style shots, while a telephoto lens (such as a 70-200mm ) is great for tighter forest photography (eg, foliage, aerials, forest patterns). I'd also suggest grabbing a macro lens or at least a close-focusing lens like a 50mm prime. That way, you can shoot all sorts of little details, including leaves on the ground, fungus on logs, and flowers sprouting on the forest floor.

        Filters

        Forests are pretty dirty, so it can be helpful to mount a clear or UV filter on all your lenses. If you do go this route, be sure you purchase a high-quality model; there are a lot of cheap UV filters on the market that'll degrade optical quality. Alternatively, you can simply carry a cleaning kit and keep your lenses well-maintained (always use a microfiber cloth, not rags or towels of any type!).

        Finally, a polarizing filter can come in handy, especially if you plan to shoot fall foliage. It'll remove glare on wet leaves, deepen fall colors, and reduce reflections in bodies of water. Keep in mind, however, that polarizers reduce the amount of light coming into your camera, so you'll definitely need that tripod!

        The best forest photography settings

        To take a fantastic forest photo, you need to master your camera settings. The best settings vary based on the type of image you want to capture, but you'll want to start by setting your camera to Manual mode , which will grant you complete control over the image exposure. Another reliable choice is Aperture Priority mode .

        If you aim to capture a scene with deep depth of field, meaning an image that's sharp from the foreground to the background, a narrow aperture is the way to go. Often, a setting of f/8 or higher achieves this effect. Such a setting is effective because it allows the viewer to fully immerse themselves in the scene:

        On the flip side, a wider aperture can create a shallow depth of field, where a single element is in sharp focus while the background blurs. This technique is excellent for highlighting specific subjects like a leaf or a tree:

        In most cases, a narrow aperture will likely serve you better, but don't neglect the power of a well-composed wide-aperture shot.

        Once you've selected your aperture, set your ISO to its base value, usually ISO 100, and pick a shutter speed based on exposure considerations. The idea is to ensure there's enough detail in the shadows and highlights of the scene.

        But bear in mind: To achieve a deep depth of field with an ISO of 100, you'll often require a longer shutter speed. This means a tripod is essential to prevent blur in your images. Additionally, if the branches of the trees are swaying in the wind, the longer shutter speed might cause motion blur, whether you use a tripod or not. Whether this effect is desirable is a matter of personal preference. If you'd rather avoid it, you can always increase your ISO and shutter speed simultaneously.

        12 forest photography ideas and tips

        Now that you know the forest photo basics, it's time to really delve into the tips, techniques, and ideas that'll elevate your shots, starting with:

        1. Take proper safety precautions

        Before you head off into the forest – especially if you plan to go on a multi-day trip – consider any potential dangers. It can be easy to get lost in forests, plus they're often dark and feature rough terrain. And if you're not careful, you might get hit by a storm or a flash flood.

        Always tell someone where you plan to be walking, and make sure you carry a phone that'll maintain a signal throughout your entire trip. Be sure to bring food, water, a map (if available, a topographical map is always best), a compass, sunscreen, and bug spray.

        I'd also encourage you to bring rain gear for you and your camera. A waterproof covering will keep your camera safe, and unless your backpack is waterproof, I'd recommend carrying a cover for it, too. And bring a dry towel or rag to remove moisture, dirt, or rain from any exposed gear.

        2. Go out when the light is right

        Forest photography, unlike most types of landscape photography , can be done at any time of day – even in bright, direct sunlight.

        You see, the forest canopy will filter out some of the harsh light, creating a more subdued lighting situation, one that you'd normally expect to find after just sunrise and before sunset.

        So don't be afraid to go out on sunny days (though midday clouds can be even better!). If you do find that the light is too strong, you can always try shooting in black and white . Look for interesting shadows, powerful patterns, and high-contrast edges.

        That said, forests are pretty magical around sunrise and sunset, so I'd urge you to head out during the early hours of the morning or late in the evening. If the forest is near water, you may get some ground fog, which can add lots of mood to your photos:

        Note that forest photography during the golden hour tends to feature lovely warm light that gives trees a sort of fairy-forest look – while forest photography during the blue hour tends to feature soft, cool light that gives a more ethereal vibe.

        3. Try to include a nice foreground subject

        A truly compelling forest photo does more than just capture the scene. It invites the viewer on a journey, guiding their eyes from the foreground to the background. This is where your composition skills come into play. What better way to create this sense of movement and depth than by incorporating an engaging foreground subject?

        You could find a cluster of wildflowers, an interesting rock formation, or a set of gnarled roots. The idea is to have an object that grabs the viewer's attention and then, through clever composition, leads them into the wider forest scene. Sometimes, something as simple as a fallen leaf can be a wonderful foreground element that complements the expansive woodland backdrop.

        Getting low and close to your foreground element can emphasize its importance. But if you use this approach, be cautious – you'll need to set your aperture and point of focus carefully to ensure both the foreground and the background are sharp. Even the smallest shift in focus can cause blurring in one area or another. It's a delicate balancing act, but when you get it right, the results can be stunning.

        4. Don't forget to shoot in portrait orientation

        Most landscape shooters create horizontal compositions out of habit, but when it comes to forest photography, this is a mistake!

        Yes, you can capture stunning horizontal forest images, but I'd also encourage you to try shooting vertical photos.

        The vertical format will allow you to capture more of the (tree) scene, and it'll also give your images a sense of height. Make sure you pay careful attention to the edges of the frame – you don't want to cut off any key elements! – and keep the horizon level. While you can always correct crookedness in post-processing, you'll lose pixels along the way, which is never a good thing!

        Also, if you're not sure whether a scene will look best in the vertical or horizontal format, just take both shots. Once you're in the editing room, you can evaluate the compositions and see which works best.

        5. Color contrast is key

        One drawback to shooting in a forest environment is the lack of color contrast. Unless it's autumn, the majority of your environment will most likely be composed of green leaves and/or brown tree trunks, which can lead to bland, boring photos.

        So you should do whatever you can to add pops of color.

        For instance, patches of brightly colored flowers can offer an eye-catching touch. Same with colorful insects!

        And even if you can't find a colorful subject in the area, you can always try to use the light. By including golden-hour sun or flare in the frame, you'll get beautiful oranges and reds (which will give your shot a more vibrant look).

        6. Try black and white

        Sometimes, when you're shooting in a forest, nothing seems right. The light doesn't hit the way you want, the colors feel off, or you just don't get a sense of drama from your subjects.

        This is a common issue among forest photographers; it's due to the general consistency of color from scene to scene, and how too many greens and browns make it hard to highlight a subject.

        But if you shoot in black and white, you can ignore the color monotony, and you can instead concentrate on the light and tones and composition. Look for interesting atmospheric effects such as fog, and do what you can to organize forest chaos into orderly structures.

        Note that you can create black-and-white images in two ways:

        You can switch your camera to its black-and-white mode, or you can work in color and convert to black and white during post-processing.

        Either is fine, but the two methods do have their pros and cons. If you work in black and white, you'll be able to review the monochrome image on your LCD (and if you shoot mirrorless, you can preview the scene through the EVF).

        On the other hand, if you work in color, you have the choice of converting to black and white or keeping the original shot. (This is an option afforded to all RAW photographers , whether shooting in color or black and white – but if you shoot JPEGs, you won't be able to convert a black and white image to a color file.)

        7. Seek out intimate shots

        While capturing the grandeur of the forest is a wonderful experience, sometimes it's the smaller, intimate details that create the most meaningful images. These images showcase the hidden beauty of the woodland, the little elements that you might miss when you're focusing on the wider scene.

        Switch your mindset from the expansive to the minute. Instead of looking up at the towering trees, look down and notice the patterns in the fallen leaves or the way the moss blankets a fallen log. If you have a macro lens, you can get especially up close and personal with your subjects so you can create images that offer a different, more intimate perspective.

        A few drops of water on a leaf, the texture of tree bark, a small stream winding its way through the undergrowth, or even a lone mushroom sprouting from the forest floor – these can all be extraordinary subjects. Each element adds a different layer of appreciation of the forest and can bring you beyond the traditional forest photo into a realm of unique, detailed woodland imagery.

        8. Photograph in every season and all types of weather

        Forests are not static; they are living entities that transform dramatically with the changing seasons and weather conditions. And as a forest photographer, you should strive to embrace this variability, rather than avoid it.

        Summer, with its lush green canopy, offers opportunities for photos bursting with life and vitality. In autumn, forests turn into a riot of color, with the reds, yellows, and oranges creating a stunning backdrop for your images.

        But don't forget about spring, when new leaves bud and flowers carpet the forest floor. And winter, despite its challenges, can produce some of the most magical forest images. Snow-covered branches and frost-covered leaves can create enchanting scenes straight out of a fairytale.

        Forests also provide striking scenes in varying weather conditions. Fog and rain can transform the familiar into the mysterious and the mystical. Photographing forests in near-whiteout conditions or on misty mornings can give your images an abstract or impressionistic feel, emphasizing the shapes and forms of the forest rather than the individual trees.

        Of course, if you do shoot in these conditions, remember to protect your camera gear. Working with a rain cover is a great starting point, and whenever possible, change your batteries and memory cards in a dry, covered location.

        With a bit of preparation, you'll be ready to capture the forest's many moods – in any weather and every season.

        9. Capture that classic “path through a forest” photo

        Photographs of paths winding through forests have a mesmerizing charm, so it's no surprise they are a staple in forest photography.

        Sure, they're popular, and yes, you might even say they've become a bit of a cliché. But remember, clichés are clichés for a reason. They work. They appeal to something universal within us. A path through the forest isn't just a path. It's a metaphor for the journey of life, full of twists, turns, and surprising discoveries.

        What makes a forest path so visually fascinating is its ability to act as a leading line in your composition, drawing the viewer's eye into and around the image. It adds depth and dimension, creating a structural pathway that naturally invites exploration.

        So whenever you head into a new forest, spend some time photographing its paths. How you capture it is completely up to you. Yes, you can go for the classic shot: path in the middle, trees rising majestically on either side. It's a time-tested composition that never fails to impress. But let me urge you to think outside the box a bit. Play around with the composition. Frame the path off-center, try shooting from an unexpected angle. There's a whole world of creative possibilities waiting for you.

        Pro tip: An overcast or dreary day can add an extra layer of moodiness, creating a more compelling visual narrative.

        10. Photograph on the forest edges

        Being deep inside a forest can feel magical, like you're immersed in another world. It's an exhilarating feeling. But sometimes, especially when trees are densely packed, it can limit your options for telephoto shots from a distance.

        Here's where the forest's edge, or even a forest clearing, can come in handy. It's an area with plenty of open space that allows you to step back, mount a telephoto lens, and capture a different perspective.

        Look for patterns formed by tree trunks and branches. Forget about seeing them as trunks and branches; start seeing them as lines and shapes. Try to create an abstract composition that leads the viewer's eye around the frame.

        Sure, it might take some persistence and a lot of shots. But believe me, when you manage to capture that stunning image, it'll all be worth it. You might even end up with a photo worth framing and hanging on your living room wall!

        11. Post-process to enhance your forest photos

        Post-processing is an essential part of forest photography; it's how you refine your photos and really make them pop.

        I'd recommend you start your editing workflow by making basic corrections (exposure, white balance , cropping, etc.). Then go into the more advanced adjustments, such as targeted contrast and color grading .

        Lighting tends to be more dramatic in the forest and can result in gorgeous rays hitting the forest floor – so draw attention to these by adding contrast to the sunlit areas. You might also try applying a bit of Vibrance to the overall image and playing around with the hue and saturation of individual colors to bring out a natural feel in the shot.

        For my own images, I like to decrease the Lightroom Clarity slider , which gives a dreamy or magical feel. I then apply local adjustments to important areas of the photos, such as the main subject. During the latter editing phase, I'll often use a Brush to boost the Clarity and the sharpness for a little extra crispness.

        But there's no single best workflow for forest photography. It's really all about experimenting and finding what works for you!

        12. Leave the forest as you found it

        The forest is beautiful, mysterious, and amazing. It's worth preserving for the next generation, so please, please, please do whatever you can to keep it clean.

        Whenever you're out shooting, make sure you clean up all your trash, including plastic bags and water bottles. And if you see trash left by others, consider cleaning that up, too.

        Also, respect the environment. Don't get too close to wildlife, and don't disturb sensitive plants or trees (by trampling over them, climbing them, etc.).

        Little things like that may seem trivial, but if we all take care of the environment, we can have a positive effect on our natural world, and we can keep it in good health for generations to come.

        Plus, there's an element of self-interest to consider: The cleaner the forest, the better your photos will look!

        Forest photography: final words

        We've journeyed together through the enchanting world of forest photography, sharing crucial tips and effective strategies to help you capture the beauty of the woods. By now, you've gained a solid understanding of the gear, settings, and techniques needed to turn your forest excursions into stunning photo ops.

        Sure, translating the mesmerizing charm of forests into photographs might still feel challenging. Remember though, every professional photographer started where you are now. With the knowledge you've gained from this guide, you're already steps ahead, ready to tackle those intricate details and dynamic lighting conditions that make forest photography such a fascinating pursuit.

        下一个是什么？ Get out there and put these insights to work! The forest is calling, and it's time to answer with your camera in hand. Experiment, explore, and above all, enjoy the process. There's nothing quite like capturing the magic of the woods and sharing it with the world.

        Forest photography FAQ

        What focal length should I use to photograph forests?

        Variety is your friend! Both wide-angle lenses and telephoto lenses can work magic in a forest setting. And don't forget a macro lens for those intimate detail shots.

        What shutter speed is best for forest photography?

        As a rule of thumb, I recommend a longer shutter speed, often below 1/100s. This compensates for the limited lighting you often find within forests.

        What's the best time of day to take pictures in the forest?

        I'm a big fan of the early morning – you get fewer people and occasionally beautiful fog. But you can also shoot in the afternoon and even at midday (especially if it's cloudy!).

        Yes, a tripod is very useful. Given the lower light conditions of most forests, a tripod will prevent camera shake and allow you to use optimal settings for the shot.

        2.携带独脚架

        足球摄影装备的另一个重要建议是什么？

        带上独脚架。是的，您可以手持笨重的 70-200mm f/2.8 镜头，甚至是 400mm 的怪物，但为什么要把所有的压力都放在您的手臂上呢？这就是独脚架的用武之地。它是您在足球场上最好的朋友，为您的装备提供支撑并让您的手臂免受疲劳。

        那么为什么我对独脚架评价如此之高呢？嗯，它们可以防止您的手臂太快疲劳。它们纤薄、轻便且易于携带 - 非常适合突然改变位置或调整角度。另外，它们还有助于减少相机抖动。这在处理长焦镜头时至关重要，因为长焦镜头因抖动引起的模糊而臭名昭著。

        我们不要忘记，许多足球比赛都是在昏暗的室内灯光下或日落之后进行的。在如此具有挑战性的照明条件下，即使是微小的相机抖动也会导致照片模糊。但是独脚架？它可以像岩石一样稳定您的相机，确保拍摄清晰的照片。

        我保证您不会花太多钱购买一个像样的独脚架，而且它们很容易打包和携带。最后一个建议：带上一张小露营凳。相信我，您的背部会感谢您，您会发现低角度拍摄可以为您的足球照片带来新鲜、引人入胜的视角。

        3. 仔细选择足球摄影设置

        我喜欢用手动模式拍摄；它给了我足够的灵活性，让我可以根据需要调整设置以应对不断变化的光线。如果您不习惯在手动模式下工作， 快门优先模式是您的最佳选择（并且它特别适合处理有阳光和阴影的场地）。

        您需要选择正确的快门速度来定格动作。我建议高级玩家将 1/800 秒作为绝对最小值（不过，如果您拍摄年轻玩家，可以将快门速度降低至 1/500 秒左右）。事实上，在拍摄快节奏的运动时，快门速度越高越好，因此，如果您有空间将快门提高到 1/1000 秒、1/2000 秒，甚至 1/4000 秒，那就这么做吧。

        也就是说，如果操作正确，超慢快门速度可以创造出一些奇妙且极具艺术性的图像。以 1/30 秒工作是一个很好的起点，如果您发现捕捉到太多模糊，只需将快门速度加快几个档次即可。相反，如果最终模糊太少，则可能需要降低快门速度。

        如果您使用快门优先模式，那么您的相机将为您选择光圈 - 但您可以通过选择快门速度间接控制它。如果您使用手动模式，则需要直接选择光圈。那么什么光圈最好呢？

        对于单人拍摄，f/2.8 通常是理想的选择，因为它可以很好地隔离主体。然而，当拍摄多个球员的瞬间（例如铲球）时，如果光线充足，请使用 f/4（它会稍微增加景深）。当然，有些镜头无法达到 f/2.8 甚至 f/4，在这种情况下，只需使用可用的最大光圈即可。

        您还需要选择ISO ，我鼓励您使用它来简单地填补光圈-快门速度组合和您想要实现的亮度之间的差距。最好保持 ISO 尽可能低——ISO 越高，图像中的噪点就越多——所以在明亮的日子里，我经常使用 ISO 400。低光场景——例如，在黄昏、夜间、室内或阴天拍摄时——需要提高 ISO，因此可能需要 ISO 800、1600 或更高。

        花一些时间测试相机上的不同 ISO 设置，因为不同型号处理高 ISO 的方式不同。如今，您通常可以在 ISO 1600 下工作且噪音最小，但这实际上在很大程度上取决于您的相机，因此在出发拍摄之前请确保您知道它的性能。

        此外， 选择正确的自动对焦模式对于拍摄清晰的照片绝对重要。不要使用相机的 AF-S（或 One-Shot）模式；确保将相机切换到 AF-C（或 AI-Servo），这样当拍摄对象移动时，它会不断重新获得焦点。

        如果您的相机提供良好的跟踪模式，请使用它！您希望能够尽可能有效地跟随玩家，如果您必须在拍摄对象移动时不断重新选择焦点，您将错过太多镜头。

        最后，相机的连拍模式绝对可以改变游戏规则。您可能知道它是连续拍摄模式，但无论您喜欢哪个名称，该工具都可以让您在短短几秒钟内拍摄出一系列照片。

        有了连拍模式，您不再担心错过瞬间的镜头。您有能力定格眨眼间逝去的令人心碎的时刻。不过，有一点需要注意：您使用连拍模式的次数越多，最终获得的照片就越多。这意味着需要花费更多的时间对所有这些进行分类，但在我看来，为了捕捉到精彩的镜头而付出的代价很小。

        4. 处于正确的位置

        与任何运动一样，如果你能坐在正确的位置，你将有更好的机会击中关键球。我通常建议从几个特定的​​地方开始工作，如下图所示：

        • 位置 1：在角球附近（稍微在球门线后面）工作可以让您在球员带球冲向您时进行精彩的射门。您还可以获得一些精彩的进球。这个位置非常通用，因为你可以很好地混合所有东西。
        • 位置 2：在两个进球之间工作是一种很好的射门方式（因为您通常可以在一个帧中同时捕捉守门员和射门者）。您还可以捕捉在球场上奔跑的球员，但如果他们是在两侧奔跑，则镜头可能不会那么正面。
        • 位置 3：对于一些变化，尝试从靠近角球的边线射门。当持球球员在球场上跑动时，您将能够捕捉到一些精彩的平移镜头。通常，您无法从 3 号位置获得很多出色的射门机会，但如果动作发生在中场周围，您也许能够捕捉到一些精彩的铲球照片。

        我不建议你选择一个地点并留在同一个地方进行游戏；相反，在一个位置坐一会儿，然后中场休息左右走动。这样，您就可以捕获各种图像。

        无论你做什么，都不要试图跟着球跑来跑去。你将永远奔跑而不拍照！最好坐在一个位置上，等待行动发生。

        庆祝活动。这些可能来自刚刚进球的球队，或者在终场哨响后来自赢得比赛的球队。

        6.了解游戏

        就像教练一样，要在足球摄影方面表现出色，您需要对比赛了如指掌。如果您已经是一名足球迷，那就太好了！以这种热情为借口，观看更多比赛，分析玩家策略，并深入研究鲜为人知的规则。您永远不知道什么时候一点点信息可以帮助您拍摄出令人惊叹的照片。

        不是足球迷？没问题。是时候阅读书籍、收听评论，或许还可以加入当地联赛以获得身临其境的体验。对游戏的深入了解使您能够在事件发生之前进行预测，从而在镜头后为您带来明显的优势。

        此外，了解你要射击的球队和球员可以给你带来额外的优势。研究他们的风格、优点和缺点。特别关注关键球员，了解他们独特的战术。明星球员标志性的滑铲或头球进球，如果在正确的时刻捕捉到，可能会成为一次真正精彩的射门。

        7.不要害怕从小事做起

        您可能会想以球迷的身份观看比赛并开始拍照。然而，大镜头通常不允许通过安检，而且黄金位置通常禁止粉丝进入。所以最好走一条不同的路。

        把你的镜头转向当地联赛怎么样？即使是高中比赛也可以提供充足的练习机会。伸出援手，寻求许可，让自己进入行动的核心。这里的关键是一致性。尽可能多地参加比赛并专注于提高自己的技能。每次点击，您都会注意到改进。

        随着您收藏的精彩镜头不断增多，为什么不让它们重见天日呢？当地报纸可能有兴趣展示您的作品。不要羞于发送几张您最好的照片。让他们一睹您带来的成果。

        请记住，每次点击都会扩展您的投资组合。继续拍照，继续分享，很快，您就会发现自己已经准备好申请专业演出。有了正确的联系和一点运气，您很可能最终会在大联盟中进行射击！

        8. 捕捉干净的背景

        好吧，我们来谈谈背景。当然，球员们抢尽了风头，他们也应该这么做。但他们的比赛环境可能会决定你的投篮成败。杂乱或分散注意力的背景可能会分散玩家的注意力。相反，干净、整洁的背景将突出球员并为您的照片带来专业的感觉。

        当你在球场上时，请密切注意周围的环境。识别背景中任何潜在的干扰，并尽量避免对着它们进行拍摄。你不只是在观看比赛；你还在观看比赛。你看到的超越了它。

        在背景中创建令人愉悦的模糊效果也可以产生巨大的效果。这种模糊效果（称为散景）有助于将玩家与背景分开，并使任何干扰不那么明显。为了获得最佳的散景效果，请确保使用大光圈。此外，在球员离你较近和远离背景时拍摄他们可以增强模糊效果。

        还有一个建议：考虑放低姿态。这样，您的背景将是体育场的墙壁和人群，而不是草坪。

        9. 拍摄一些广角镜头

        大多数时候，作为一名足球摄影师，您会发现自己被特写动作镜头所吸引。这是可以理解的；长焦镜头可帮助您深入比赛，以令人惊叹的细节捕捉那些充满活力的时刻。但也有更广泛的镜头的地方。

        其一，更宽的镜头可以提供不同的视角，并为您的照片增添多样性。它还可以在更广阔的背景下构建比赛，捕捉体育场的氛围、欢呼的人群，甚至露天比赛期间头顶上戏剧性的天空。

        因此，请携带广角镜头并进行实验。尝试拍摄充满兴奋球迷的体育场。在比赛的关键时刻获得整个球场的广角镜头。或者捕捉人群的集体情绪——他们的庆祝、失望以及介于两者之间的一切。

        虽然这些图像可能不像特写动作镜头那样具有强烈的冲击力，但它们有不同的用途。他们为游戏故事增添了层次，赋予其深度和丰富性。它们为您的投资组合增添了多样性。因此，下次您出去拍摄足球比赛时，请记住每隔一段时间就走远一点。它可能只会导致完成故事的镜头。

        10. 编辑并分享您的最佳镜头

        拍摄到一些精彩的照片？伟大的！但不要让你的工作随着快门的按下而结束。您的图像值得进行一些微调，以展现其最佳品质。

        首先将所有镜头传输到您最喜欢的后处理程序。快速扫描应该可以帮助您标记有希望的文件。不要想太多，只需标记那些引起您注意的即可。现在，深入研究这些标记的镜头并选择真正突出的镜头。这些是您要编辑的照片。

        剪辑不是要改变镜头，而是要增强镜头。校正白平衡、调整曝光级别并确保颜色恰到好处。清晰度的一点提升将为您的图像增添额外的清晰度。

        您还可以考虑添加晕影效果以引导观看者将注意力集中到玩家身上。但请记住，微妙是关键。您的观众应该感受到效果，而不是看到它。

        最后，选择您愿意在上面写上自己名字的图像。这些镜头讲述了游戏的故事。与世界分享它们，无论是在社交媒体、个人博客还是新闻网站上。让其他人通过您的镜头体验游戏！

        11.向最好的足球摄影师学习

        踏上足球摄影师的旅程，您绝对并不孤单。您会发现世界各地有无数熟练的足球摄影师。许多人将自己的职业生涯奉献给完善捕捉精彩比赛动作的艺术。那么为什么不向他们学习呢？

        首先探索这些经验丰富的摄影师的作品。查看他们的在线作品集和社交媒体动态。事实上，关注他们，让他们的最新照片成为您每日动态的一部分。这是定期接触高质量足球摄影的完美方式。

        现在，您不再只是为了享受浏览的乐趣。当您滚动浏览这些照片时，请进行一些侦探工作。尝试了解是什么让这些图像脱颖而出。摄影师是如何构图的？是什么让它讲故事？他们是否捕捉到了游戏的精彩瞬间或微妙的细微差别？

        记下什么吸引了你的注意力。是镜头的角度、光线的运用、对玩家情绪的敏锐关注，还是其他什么？保持好奇心并质疑哪些元素可以融入到自己的作品中。

        请记住，这不是一次性的练习。这个过程应该持续进行。定期分析您欣赏的摄影师的作品。随着时间的推移，您不仅会学习新技术，还会开始发展自己独特的风格。你并不是想克隆别人的作品。相反，让他们的工作激励您突破自己的界限。

                想要改善您的旅行风景照片吗？从装备和规划到构图和灯光，利用这 10 个专业技巧来提升拍摄水平。

                深入旅游风景摄影，可以带你到天涯海角，一览巍峨的高山、苍翠的山峦、宁静的湖泊、蜿蜒的河流。这种类型是日常风景摄影的一个进步——它是为了捕捉遥远目的地的纯粹辉煌。

                那么如何才能让你的镜头从普通变成非凡呢？嗯，这就是我们在这里讨论的内容。我列出了 10 个技巧，可以帮助您立即提升图像质量。

                因此，无论您是在旅行中拍摄风景照片的新手，还是一位经验丰富的摄影爱好者，寻求一些新鲜的见解，本指南都是为您量身定制的。让我们开始吧！

                1. 仔细选择（并研究）您的目的地

                在哪里拍摄旅行风光摄影？这是一个价值百万美元的问题。世界各地有如此多令人瞠目结舌的地方， 选择一个地方既令人兴奋又充满挑战。

                为了帮助您做出决定，请问问自己：哪些风景让我着迷？我是否梦想着崎岖的山脉、 布满卵石的海滩或郁郁葱葱的瀑布？深入了解您的相机眼睛正在寻找的细节。然后将您的答案与选中这些框的少数目的地进行匹配。

                不要让天气、费用或身体挑战影响您的精神，但请确保这些因素在您的选择过程中发挥作用。我们都受到预算的限制，因此请明智地选择并获得最大的回报。如果您的预算充足，那就让这成为您的梦想之旅吧！

                个人比较推荐英国的湖区。这里是旅游风景摄影师的天堂，拥有风景如画的山丘、宁静的湖泊以及通往令人惊叹的有利位置的无尽远足小径。

                但请记住，情人眼里出西施，世界上到处都是美丽的地方。其他一些值得考虑的绝佳选择包括冰岛雄伟的峡湾、尼泊尔雄伟的喜马拉雅山、美国令人惊叹的国家公园、玻利维亚超现实的盐滩、巴西伊瓜苏的瀑布以及法国普罗旺斯迷人的薰衣草田。

                2.彻底了解你的拍摄对象和地点

                你已经选定一个地点了吗？现在，更深入地挖掘。了解您选择的区域的每个角落和缝隙。注意您感兴趣的拍摄对象。探索已在同一位置拍摄的图像。谁知道呢，您可能会偶然发现该地区的风景或旅行摄影指南。这将提供一个值得拍摄的主题宝库。

                创建一个拍摄列表来组织您访问时想要捕捉的内容。记下每个地点的最佳拍摄时间。黄金时段、正午或蓝色时段——每个主题在不同的时间表现得最好。

                利用PhotoPills 等显示全天太阳方向的应用程序。这可以帮助您计划拍摄。同样，参考一天和一年中不同时间拍摄的图像来制定方法策略。

                但请记住，虽然计划您的摄影冒险很有帮助，但要保持灵活性。天气可能会发生变化，可能会出现更好的选择，或者您可能会改变对地点的想法。那完全没问题！拥抱自发性。

                3.选择合适的装备

                您可能认为一流的风景摄影需要高端、昂贵的装备。但令人惊讶的是：事实并非如此！得益于技术的飞跃，您甚至可以使用拍照手机或袖珍相机拍摄精美的旅行风景照片。那里有一大批出色的智能手机风景摄影师。

                也就是说，如果您热衷于这个爱好，您可能会想拥有一台数码单反相机或无反光镜相机。有什么大不了的？灵活性。借助一系列可供您使用的镜头，您可以轻松切换档位来拍摄不同的拍摄对象。卓越图像质量和更好地控制相机设置的奖励积分。这些相机可能有点贵，您可能还需要带几个镜头，但相信我，如果您喜欢摄影，那么它是值得的。

                准备好购物了吗？探索佳能、尼康、索尼、富士胶片、奥林巴斯和松下等值得信赖的品牌的选择。选择一款符合您的需求和预算的产品。也可以在您的购物车中添加一个漂亮的风景镜头，最好是具有广角功能的镜头。我建议从 24-70mm 或 16-35mm 镜头开始，但 18-55mm 套装镜头也是不错的选择。

                还有一件必备品吗？坚固的旅行三脚架。这可能看起来不方便，但它可以对图像清晰度产生一些真正的魔力。不用担心，一个好的碳纤维三脚架并不像您想象的那么笨重。它们设计得轻巧紧凑。

                4. 拍摄全景，捕捉广阔的美景

                当您来到这个地点时，您会被广阔的景色所震撼。怎么办？是时候推出全景图了。它可以让您将大量的精彩融入到一个框架中。

                想知道如何创建全景图？简单的。将相机安装在三脚架上，然后在景观中旋转三脚架头时拍摄一系列重叠的图像。 （请记住，每个图像应与其邻居共享至少三分之一的场景！）

                回到家，您需要使用软件程序将这些图像拼接在一起。即使像 Lightroom Classic 这样的基本工具也具有强大的全景拼接功能，因此这一步将变得轻而易举。

                专业提示：广角镜头可以为全景照片带来奇妙的效果。它可以让您捕捉令人惊叹的天空，并包括更多的前景和背景，为您的图像增加深度和比例。结果？壮观的镜头反映了一览无遗的壮丽景观。

                5.研究你的相机手册

                我注意到以下几点：新手常常一头扎进摄影领域，而不去学习相机的使用技巧。糟糕的举动。

                想象一下，在异国他乡，捕捉一生一次的景色，却带着一张装满低劣照片的存储卡回来，这一切都归功于本可以避免的相机设置错误。

                这就是相机手册的用武之地。花时间了解相机的工作原理，并熟悉其出色的功能。这将让您优化关键设置并避免诸如以不必要的高 ISO 进行拍摄等陷阱。

                你猜怎么着？当您在旅行时，对相机的深入了解不仅可以提高您的摄影游戏水平，还可以增加乐趣！有了新发现的知识，您将更加渴望探索和捕捉。

                6. 打持久战

                作为一名摄影爱好者，您知道探索新地点的兴奋感。但是，当您沉浸在陌生风景的美丽之中时，不要失去注意力至关重要。当然，您可能会忍不住想要捕捉每一个吸引您眼球的迷人细节。但重要的是要退后一步，着眼于大局。

                通过镜头看到一切可能很诱人，但请记住，您来这里是为了真正特别的镜头，而不仅仅是普通的镜头。过于全神贯注于随意拍摄可能会让您失去梦想捕捉到的真正壮丽的场景。要拍摄一张完美的日落海滩或雪山照片，耐心和决心是您的盟友。

                例如，上面显示的图像不需要运气。这是坚持的成果。我走了好几英里，绕过人群和四轮驱动车，才发现这个宁静的场景。在光线消失之前，我能够手持拍摄一些照片，但如果我停下来捕捉沿途每一个有趣的景色，我可能会错过这颗宝石。

                因此，当您开始考虑特定的拍摄时，请坚持到底。也就是说，如果出现更有吸引力的机会，请准备好改变策略。灵活性是风景摄影的秘密武器，识别意想不到的黄金机会是一项值得磨练的技能。

                7. 尽可能使用三脚架

                在上面有关装备的部分中，我鼓励您投资购买优质的三脚架。不过，如果你不好好利用三脚架，它就毫无价值，所以我提醒你：尽可能使用三脚架！

                当白天临近黄昏，手持拍摄不再可行时，您的三脚架可以成为救星。一旦你的快门速度降至 1/100 秒以下，三脚架就会成为你的后盾，为拍摄清晰的图像提供坚如磐石的支撑。加分点 – 它可以让您发挥长时间曝光效果，将流动的河流或飘浮的云朵变成令人惊叹的、空灵的视觉效果。

                然而，三脚架不仅仅是夜间工具。即使在光天化日之下，使用三脚架也能鼓励您以更周全的方式构图。它可以让您在光线条件达到峰值之前很好地设置和完善您的构图。这样，当理想时刻到来时，您可以专注于捕捉场景，而不是摆弄画面。

                8.保持水平线

                这是风景摄影初学者常见的陷阱——倾斜地平线。在捕捉鼓舞人心的景色的兴奋中，您可能会忘记这个简单但至关重要的元素。

                所以这里有一个快速提醒：密切关注地平线。努力将其对齐以获得更加平衡和水平的照片。请记住，所有水平元素都应与框架底部平行，所有垂直元素应完全垂直，除非您的目标是故意形成角度的透视。

                是的，您可以在后处理过程中修复倾斜的地平线。但请记住，拉直图像意味着剪掉边缘周围的一些像素。您需要拉直的次数越多，丢失的像素就越多。那么为什么不把它钉在现场呢？

                对于那些在直线视野中苦苦挣扎的人来说，这是一个专业提示：考虑使用气泡水平仪。将其安装到相机的热靴上，无论您是低角度还是高角度，甚至是手持时，您都可以直接拍摄！

                9.不断考虑照明

                旅游风景摄影游戏的主要参与者之一？光。它有点像变色龙，一天中的质量都在变化，从柔软、温暖到中性和粗糙。甚至您相对于拍摄对象的位置也会影响照明角度。

                风光摄影中不存​​在通用的“完美光线” 。这是您的风格和您所拍摄的主题之间的个人舞蹈。但请记住这一点：永远、永远对光保持警惕！

                首先想象你的主题。考虑一下它们什么时候会看起来最好——在阳光充足的中午，或者在一天的开始和结束时，光线更加引人注目和金色。如果您不开车旅行，请确保您的计划时间与您的交通方式同步。并且不要忘记计划如何准时到达您的位置。

                接下来，仔细考虑照明方向。正面照明会给你更多的细节，侧面照明会带来浓重阴影的戏剧效果，而逆光虽然处理起来很棘手，但可以提升拍摄的气氛。如果您不确定，请尝试一下！在不同的灯光下点击一下，多拍总比少拍好！

                10. 努力练习你的作文

                出色的旅行风景照片不仅仅取决于良好的照明；还取决于光线。它们也涉及优秀的构图。如何在画面中排列元素、如何构建镜头——它可以为每张图像添加节奏和平衡。以海景照片为例。地平线应该在哪里？在底部、顶部还是中间？这就是作文的精髓，当然需要你的注意！

                在旅行期间进行风景构图可以为您的信心和技能创造奇迹。在旅行前阅读各种作曲技巧，并在现场时尝试实施它们。

                拍摄时，寻找引导视线穿过风景并吸引观众的引导线，就像穿过荒野的蜿蜒小路一样。并尝试三分法则。尝试将主要拍摄对象放置在偏离中心的位置，或者将地平线置于画面的三分之一或三分之二处。

                一开始你可能会觉得作曲很技术性，甚至很平凡，但给它一个机会。您很快就会发现它对您的照片的影响，并意识到它并不像看起来那么令人畏惧！
